facts.text: Naraindas (appellant) is brother of Vallabhdas (respondent 1) and Durgaprasad (respondent 2), and son of Smt. Sukhrani (respondent 3).

Arbitration proceedings in 1932 between appellant and respondents 1 to 3 on one side and Pannalal and Smt. Dulari Bahu on the other side, relating to partition of property and maintenance claim by Dulari Bahu.

Award given in 1932 proceedings made rule of court on 13-12-1933: Dulari Bahu to get Rs. 12/- per mensem maintenance from appellant and brothers; charge on house allotted to appellant and respondents 1-3; if unpaid, house to be sold, Rs. 3,000/- deposited in bank, interest to Dulari, principal on her death: Rs. 2,000/- to appellant and brothers, Rs. 1,000/- to Pannalal.
Maintenance increased to Rs. 30/- per mensem in suit decided on 8-10-1949.

Appellant and brothers failed to pay maintenance; Dulari Bahu executed claim, got houses at Jabalpur sold by court auction; purchased by Sitaram and Laxminarain (respondents 4 and 5) for Rs. 22,000/-; obtained sale certificate.
Respondents 4 and 5 took proceedings for possession but resisted by respondent No. 1; appellant and brothers claimed deposited amount with respondents 4 and 5.

Agreement dated 8th April 1955 appointing four arbitrators between appellant, brothers, mother vs. respondents 4 and 5: respondents 4 and 5 to have no claim in houses; arbitrators to award amounts payable by parties and maintenance to Dulari Bahu and Sukhrani Bahu.

Arbitrators' award dated 20th October 1956: For Dulari Bahu, Rs. 3,000/- withdrawn from court and deposited with Durgaprasad (respondent 2), liable to pay Rs. 30/- pm maintenance; on her death, Rs. 1,000/- to Pannalal, Rs. 2,000/- to Durgaprasad; charge on house allotted to Durgaprasad; right of residence in a room.

Objections filed against 1956 award; Additional District Judge, Jabalpur set aside award: affected rights of Dulari Bahu (not party to agreement); reference and award not adjustment, invalid; in excess of agreement.
Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. First Appeal No. 60 of 1960 on 27-4-1964 reversed Additional District Judge, held no infirmity, made award rule of court.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate from High Court.
Dulari Bahu died about three years ago (before judgment).

legal_issues.text: Whether the award is invalid because Dulari Bahu was an interested party not joined in the arbitration agreement.
Whether an out-of-court reference to arbitration requires all parties to sign the award for it to be made a rule of the court.
Whether prior litigation regarding the house prevents it from being subject matter of arbitration.

petitioner_arguments.text: Dulari Bahu was interested party in dispute; not joined in arbitration agreement; reference and award invalid.
Reference out of court; not all parties signed award in token of acceptance; cannot be made rule of court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Jugaldas Demodar Modi Co. v. Pursottam Umedbhai Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Earlier litigation about house allotted to appellant and brothers prevents it being subject of arbitration.

court_reasoning.text: Dispute referred related to houses sold in auction; Dulari's interest only in maintenance recovery from Rs. 3,000/- deposit per earlier award; her rights intact, not affected; charge preserved; she did not object; died three years ago, question academic.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dulari Bahu did not sign agreement but her rights unaffected; no objection raised by her.

court_reasoning.text: Out-of-court reference valid without suit pending; consent needed only at reference stage, not award; distinguishes cases with pending suits; proviso to s.47 Arbitration Act applies only if suit pending.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No suit pending; parties can refer without court intervention; award enforceable without all signing.

court_reasoning.text: Parties agreed to refer dispute; prior litigation on property does not prevent fresh arbitration reference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement to arbitrate overrides prior litigation history.

holdings.text: Award valid; Dulari Bahu's rights not prejudicially affected.
Out-of-court arbitration award enforceable without all parties signing, if no suit pending.
Prior litigation does not bar arbitration on same property if parties agree.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jugaldas Demodar Modi Co. v. Pursottam Umedbhai Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealt with arbitration during pendency of suit; not applicable here as no suit pending.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso allows award as compromise if suit pending and parties consent; not applicable without pending suit.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld Madhya Pradesh High Court judgment making the arbitration award dated 20-10-1956 a rule of the court, finding no infirmity in proceedings or award.

key_quotes.text: The rights of Dulari Bahu in this respect remained intact and were in no way affected by the award dated 20th October, 1956.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding rejecting invalidity due to non-joinder of Dulari Bahu.

key_quotes.text: It is always open to parties to refer a dispute to arbitration without the intervention of the Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies validity of out-of-court references absent pending suit.
